title: 110_hr2030
content:
The "1901 Missouri African American Expulsion Commission Act of 2007" establishes a commission called the "1901 Missouri African American Expulsion Commission" with specific duties. The Commission shall investigate the expulsion of African-American residents in Missouri cities between August 1894 and August 1901, including causes, home vandalism, criminal acts, and mob activity. It will also identify relatives or individuals who suffered losses. The Commission will research and develop a historical record of the expulsion of African-American residents in Missouri cities between August 1894 and August 1901. It will also identify individuals who suffered losses and make recommendations on the feasibility and appropriate method of providing reparations. The Commission will focus on researching the expulsion of African-American residents in Missouri cities between August 1894 and August 1901. The Commission, composed of seven members appointed by the House of Representatives and the Senate, will focus on researching the expulsion of African-American residents in Missouri cities between August 1894 and August 1901. Appointing authorities must select individuals with expertise in politics or government for the Commission. Each member serves a specific term and vacancies are filled accordingly. Each member of the Commission is appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Basic pay for members is based on the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission members are prohibited from receiving additional compensation. They will receive travel expenses and per diem. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Chairman is elected by the members and determines the frequency of meetings. The Commission members are prohibited from receiving additional compensation and will receive travel expenses and per diem. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Chairman, elected by the members, determines the frequency of meetings. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION AND EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS.

The Chairman can appoint staff and set their pay, hire experts and consultants with Commission approval, and request personnel from federal agencies to assist the Commission. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, and devises for its work, use the United States mails, and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report to Congress within 18 months of its first meeting, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 10 days after submitting the report. Appropriations are authorized as needed for the Act.
